description: From Middle English outschewen, equivalent to out- +‎ show. Compare German ausschauen (“to look, appear; to look out”).

entries.meaning: That which is shown openly, evinced, or revealed.
examples: We deal only with the facts, the outshow of the theory to which we object.

verbs.description: outshow (third-person singular simple present outshows, present participle outshowing, simple past outshowed, past participle outshown)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To show or present publicly; exhibit openly.
examples: He blushed to see another Sun below, / Ne durst again his fiery face outshow.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To surpass or exceed in showing; exceed in being shown, especially in contest, competition, or rivalry.
examples: Mazurka 13th, now owned by Mr. Streator, at ten years old Is dam of eight living calves at single births, and we don't know a cow of her age that can outshow her.
